message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Infiltrating lobular carcinoma is typically hormone receptor-positive and HER2-positive and is typically treated with surgery and chemotherapy. Surgical resection alone is not sufficient as the cancer has already spread outside the breast. Radiotherapy alone is not sufficient as infiltrating lobular carcinoma is often multicentric and may involve multiple quadrants of the breast. Therefore, surgical resection and chemotherapy is the most appropriate management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Breast cancer in a pregnant patient can be managed with surgical resection and chemotherapy. Since the patient is pregnant, radiotherapy may not be the best option as it can be harmful to the fetus. The specific type of breast cancer found in the patient, infiltrating lobular carcinoma, can be treated with chemotherapy, especially if the cancer is estrogen receptor positive and HER2 positive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the mass is a lobular carcinoma and positive for estrogen and HER2 receptors suggest that surgical resection alone may not be enough. Chemotherapy should be added to improve the chances of survival. Radiotherapy may be considered but it should only be used in conjunction with surgical resection. Therefore, surgical resection and chemotherapy are the most appropriate management options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s diagnosis is infiltrating lobular carcinoma, which is known to be hormone receptor positive and HER2 receptor positive. Surgical resection alone is not sufficient for this type of cancer. Chemotherapy is recommended in addition to surgical resection. Radiotherapy may also be used but is not mentioned as a standalone option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The size and characteristics of the mass indicate invasive cancer, and the positive estrogen and HER2 receptors suggest high risk for recurrence. Surgical resection alone may not be enough, so chemotherapy is also needed. Radiotherapy can be added based on the final pathology result after surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Invasive lobular carcinoma is known to have a high rate of axillary lymph node involvement and a high rate of multifocality/bilaterality. Given the positive estrogen and HER2 receptors, the most appropriate management would be surgical resection and chemotherapy. Radiotherapy can be considered depending on the surgical margins and lymph node involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has infiltrating lobular carcinoma, which is positive for estrogen and HER2 receptors and negative for progesterone receptors. This is an aggressive form of breast cancer, so surgical resection alone is not enough. Chemotherapy is necessary to kill the cancer cells. Radiotherapy may also be necessary after surgery. Therefore, option (B) is the most appropriate management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is diagnosed with infiltrating lobular carcinoma, which is positive for estrogen and HER2 receptors and negative for progesterone receptors. Based on these factors, the most appropriate management would include surgical resection and chemotherapy. Surgical resection alone may not be sufficient, as there is a risk of recurrence. Radiotherapy may be used in conjunction with surgery or chemotherapy, but it is not the most appropriate initial management option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has infiltrating lobular carcinoma, which is positive for estrogen and HER2 receptors but negative for progesterone receptors, indicating that it is aggressive. Chemotherapy is the most appropriate management to treat the aggressive cancer, and surgical resection should be performed in combination. Radiation therapy may be considered based on the extent of the disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has infiltrating lobular carcinoma, which is positive for estrogen and HER2 receptors and negative for progesterone receptors, indicating that chemotherapy is necessary. Surgical resection alone is not enough as the cancer has already spread to the lymph nodes. Radiotherapy alone is also not enough as the cancer is hormone receptor positive. So, the appropriate management is surgical resection and chemotherapy.
